stem: An 82-year-old client with a history of Bipolar Disorder and Age-Related Kidney Decline is admitted for confusion. Based on the documentation in the Geriatric Psych & Renal Clearance Tracker tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Gradual decline in mental status and coordination.
Background: Lithium therapy for 25 years. CKD Stage 3.
Assessment: Client has an unsteady gait, slurred speech, and coarse tremors.
Recommendation: Critical evaluate of the drug-to-kidney ratio.

tabs.title: Renal Clearance & Lab Tracker
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Serum Lithium2.1 mEq/LToxic (> 1.5)
Estimated GFR28 mL/minModerate to Severe Impairment
Creatinine2.4 mg/dLChronically Elevated
Thyroid (TSH)8.5 mIU/LMildly High (Hypothyroid risk)

actionOptions.text: Withhold the Lithium dose and notify the provider immediately
Prepare the client for potential hemodialysis as prescribed
Administer the next scheduled dose to maintain mood stability
Increase the dose of Lithium to compensate for low clearance

parameterOptions.text: Serial Lithium levels and renal function (BUN/Creatinine/GFR)
Neurological status and motor coordination (Ataxia check)
Daily measurement of fasting blood glucose

rationale.correct: This client has Chronic Lithium Toxicity (c1) secondary to renal impairment (GFR 28). In elderly patients, lithium can accumulate insidiously even with standard doses. The level of 2.1 mEq/L combined with neuro signs (ataxia/slurred speech) is critical. The nurse must hold the drug (a1) and prepare for hemodialysis (a2) which is the preferred treatment for severe toxicity, especially when renal function is impaired. Monitoring labs (p1) and neuro status (p2) is essential.
clinicalPearls: Lithium is 100% excreted by the kidneys. If GFR drops, Lithium level goes up.
Hemodialysis is indicated if Lithium > 2.5 (Acute) or > 1.5 with severe renal/neurological symptoms (Chronic).
Long-term Lithium use can also cause Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus and Hypothyroidism.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a level of 2.1 is 'only slightly' high because it's not 3.0.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Anything over 1.5 is toxic. In chronic toxicity with renal failure, even 'lower' toxic levels can be fatal.
